properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong, gusty winds Sunday. An Alberta Clipper will bring winds gusting between 60 and 70 km/h beginning Sunday morning. Winds will then strengthen Sunday evening with gusts up to 80 km/h. Winds will diminish Monday morning. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-01T11:17:13-00:00

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong northwest winds with gusts in excess of 90 km/h continue in the lee of the Lake Winnipeg south basin. Winds will diminish later this evening. ### High winds may toss loose objects or cause tree branches to break. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-01T07:14:41-00:00

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A vigorous frontal system will move onto the north coast Sunday afternoon. Winds over Haida Gwaii and the exposed area of north coast - coastal sections will increase to southerly 90 km/h gusting to 110 Sunday afternoon and persist through early Monday morning. The front will move onto the central coast on Monday. ### High winds may toss loose objects or cause tree branches to break. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-01T14:54:27-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-10-31T22:55:27-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2000995301.2020
Area: Haida Gwaii, North Coast - coastal sections
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of about 15 cm is expected. A vigorous Pacific frontal system will move through southern Yukon beginning Sunday evening. Snow will begin falling on Sunday afternoon and increase in intensity overnight. The snow will taper off on Monday afternoon. Snowfall accumulation near 15 cm is expected for Whitehorse and 20 cm for Carcross. Strong northerly winds will also accompany this system leading to blowing snow and poor visibility. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #YTStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-01T14:52:05-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-10-31T22:53:05-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4046464144.2020
Area: Whitehorse
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snow is expected. Total snowfall: 20 to 40 cm with higher amounts possible. Locations: central Labrador and mid-Labrador coast. Time span: Monday through Tuesday afternoon. Remarks: Rain will begin over most areas Monday morning then transition to snow later in the day and persist into Tuesday morning. Conditions will improve by Tuesday afternoon. At this time, there is considerable uncertainty regarding the track of the system, which could cause snowfall amounts to vary significantly or shift to adjacent regions. Please monitor your local forecast for future updates. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-11-01T16:31:50-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-11-01T00:32:50-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0717845923.2020
Area: Rigolet and vicinity, Postville - Makkovik, Upper Lake Melville, Churchill Valley
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant wind is expected. Maximum wind gusts: 80 km/h inland to 120 km/h near the coast, with locally stronger gusts possible. Locations: Newfoundland. Time span: Monday morning to Tuesday morning. Remarks: Strong south to southeasterly winds will increase across the island through the day on Monday. A period of strong southwesterly winds may follow over western regions late Monday night into Tuesday morning. Anyone who has Halloween decorations outdoors should consider bringing them inside before Monday, as they are at risk of being tossed by the wind. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-11-01T16:34:01-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong wind gusts and local blowing snow expected tonight and Sunday morning. An Alberta Clipper will sweep through northern Ontario tonight and Sunday. Locally strong wind gusts of 70 to 80 km/h are possible as winds become northwesterly tonight. Strong winds, along with falling snow, will allow for blowing snow to reduce visibilities at times and make travel difficult. Winds will weaken by Sunday afternoon. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-01T18:34:20-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-11-01T02:35:20-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1731679593.2020

properties.Title: Les Suêtes Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. Les Suetes wind gusts expected Sunday night. Maximum wind gusts: up to 90 km/h. Locations: Margaree Harbour to Bay St Lawrence. Time span: Overnight Sunday into Monday morning. Remarks: Strong south-southeasterly winds will develop during the day Sunday and gusts up to 90 km/h are expected Sunday night. ### Loose objects may be tossed by the wind and cause injury or damage. Les Suêtes wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-01T16:55:44-00:00

properties.Title: Winter Storm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A strong weather system is forecast to affect southwestern sections of the Northwest Territories beginning Sunday afternoon and persist into early next week. Heavy snow is expected with this system, with total accumulations possibly exceeding 25 cm by Tuesday morning. The heaviest snow is predicted to fall mostly over higher terrain and over the Nahanni National Park region, however accumulations are expected in communities east of these regions as well. Warnings may be issued as confidence regarding this system increases. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NTStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-01T18:21:37-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-11-01T02:22:37-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3502076710.2020
Area: Ft. Liard Region including Nahanni Butte - Sambaa K'e
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant rain and wind is expected. Total rainfall: 30 to 50 mm. Locally higher amounts possible. Maximum wind gusts: 80 km/h inland to 120 km/h near the coast, with locally stronger gusts possible. Locations: Port aux Basques and Burgeo regions. Time span: Monday through Tuesday morning. Remarks: Rain, at times heavy, is forecast to begin Monday morning. Currently, the highest rainfall amounts are expected to be inland and over higher terrain, although coastal communities may still see significant amounts. The rain will taper off overnight into Tuesday. Strong south to southeasterly winds will increase across the island through the day on Monday. A period of strong southwesterly winds may follow late Monday night into Tuesday morning. Anyone who has Halloween decorations outdoors should consider bringing them inside before Monday, as they are at risk of being tossed by the wind. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-11-01T16:35:29-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-11-01T00:36:29-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4131358247.2020
Area: Burgeo - Ramea, Channel-Port aux Basques and vicinity
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow at times heavy tonight. Snow at times heavy will continue as an Alberta Clipper tracks eastward across Ontario. Snow mixed with rain will transition back to snow later this evening. Snowfall totals of 15 to 20 cm can be expected before the snow ends early Sunday morning. In addition, strong winds gusting up to 70 km/h will accompany the snow resulting in reduced visibilities in blow snow at times. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-01T18:31:41-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow and blowing snow tonight and Sunday. Snow will continue as an Alberta Clipper tracks eastward across Ontario. Snow will briefly change to rain this evening before changing back to snow overnight. Snowfall totals near 10 cm can be expected before the snow ends Sunday morning. In addition, strong northerly winds gusting up to 60 km/h will accompany the snow resulting in reduced visibilities in blowing snow at times. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Potentially damaging winds Sunday night. An Alberta Clipper will bring moderate winds gusting between 60 and 70 km/h tonight and Sunday. Winds will then strengthen Sunday evening with gusts up to 90 km/h. Winds will diminish Monday morning. ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. High winds may toss loose objects or cause tree branches to break. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Summary:

The exact track of the system will impact snowfall totals, however total amounts near 25 cm are expected and possibly reaching up to 50 cm in some areas. properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A long episode of rain, at times heavy, is expected. A frontal system will move onto the north coast tonight and stall over the region through Monday. North coast inland sections near Stewart will receive heavy rain tonight through Monday morning with total rainfall amounts possibly exceeding 100 mm by Monday morning. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.

Area: North Coast - inland including Stewart
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow, ice pellets, and freezing rain are expected Sunday evening and Sunday overnight. Snowfall amounts of 5-10 cm is expected in areas north of High Level by Monday morning. A nearly stationary narrow east-west band of freezing rain or ice pellets is expected to develop near High Level Sunday evening, but there is some uncertainty as to exactly where this band will form. Significant freezing rain accumulations are possible under the band, possibly approaching 5 mm of ice accumulation. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Winter storm watches are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-01T18:26:20-00:00

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with gusty winds and visibility frequently near zero in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. Blizzard conditions, significant snowfall and very cold wind chill values beginning late Sunday. A second, stronger Pacific frontal system will arrive late Sunday bringing with it significant snowfall and strong winds resulting in blizzard conditions. Blizzard conditions will last through Monday with total snowfall accumulations up to 60 cm. The strong winds will also produce very cold wind chill values as low as -30. ### Travel is expected to be very difficult or impossible due to near-zero visibility. Road closures are possible. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #YTStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-01T18:12:40-00:00

properties.Summary:
Description: Heavy rain expected Sunday night. Total Rainfall: 30 to 50 mm, with locally higher amounts possible. Time span: Sunday evening into Monday morning. Remarks: Rain at times heavy is expected to begin Sunday evening then taper to a few showers Monday morning. Generally 30 to 40 mm is expected but areas under the heaviest rain bands may see accumulations of 50 millimetres or more. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
